review: I was really excited about getting this but ended up being bothered by two things:  1, in the TV commercials and advertising, they never seem to tell you that you have to plug it in from the large round end into the TV USB (if your TV has one), or into an electrical outlet. 2, it would never connect to my wifi network. author: Adir

review: This device is already well worth the price for me as it casts Youtube and GooglePlay media seamlessly.  I also use a couple of the newly compatible apps (BeyondPod and Avia) but I really appreciate it for casting tabs from a computer.  Now people should realize that the quality of casting from a pc  is highly dependent on the computer's processing power since it is really mirroring the tabs and has to "double render".  I've tried it with three different desktop/laptops and performance is in direct correlation to the power of the processor. It actually works really well with my most recent $200 Acer Chromebook. The double-rendering, of course, does not apply to Chromecast-supported sites such as Youtube, Netflix and HBO Go, as they cast in the same way as apps from your phone--sending just the link to be picked up and rendered by the Chromecast itself.This is why the future is so exciting for this gadget.  Google has already announced plans to support a lot more apps and release the SDK soon in 2014 so that any website can incorporate the technology.  Once that happens, you won't be mirroring videos from the pc, but rather casting them in the efficient, high-performance way.
author: CAC1031

review: Google has a whole list of routers that aren't compatible with the Chromecast, or require a workaround.  I don't know if you can access the list BEFORE you buy. but it's worth a look to see.  I researched Chromecast vs. Apple TV on YouTube before buying this, and saw the two have different advantages.  Chromecast's advantages were price ($35 vs $100) and flexibility -- I have a PC and android as well as Apple products.  Apple had more features and benefits.  I chose the Chromecast - the need to purchase the new router wiped out the price advantage, however.

review: I used to use an HDMI cable to stream from laptop to TV, mainly Netflix and Youtube. Chromecast quality seems to be just as good, and no cable in the way. What's not to like? Although Google doesn't technically support doing this, you should be able to plug Chromecast directly into your receiver to get sound through your stereo speakers, rather than plugging into your TV and then having to run an audio cable to the receiver.
